content: @WG-async-sprint-planning The first sprint planning meeting is in ~one hour. Agenda is here: https://hackmd.io/@wg-async-foundations/SkZxIAabt
@WG-async-sprint-planning :wave:
wave!
Welcome everyone
so going forward, I'm going to put the agenda in the above doc and others can add to it
I think it'd be a good idea to very briefly review the general idea of "sprints", cadence, polish issues, etc
to make sure we're all on the same page etc
yeah, agreed
we're short a few owners though :(
but I just remembered that e.g. @pnkfelix is on vacation, so that's expected
maybe we're not!
I guess @eholk ?
ah, he did wave
ok, never mind me
I'm here!

nikomatsakis said:

I think it'd be a good idea to very briefly review the general idea of "sprints", cadence, polish issues, etc

let's do that when we get to sprint planning, I think
• Check in on organizational setup
is the first item on the agenda
I wanted to see if owners had a chance to parse out their initiatives and roadmaps
ok
example of an initiative is async fn fundamentals
I am in the process of moving that over to a dedicated repo
Is that something we should be doing with all the initiatives?
but the end state is that the Roadmap section of the site should link to a fully filled out version of each of these
I am not sure it makes sense for everyone
Will we keep an independent repo for each initiative and have to keep the WG's site up to date? It feels like we'd be duplicating effort there :-/
I think the idea, @Esteban Küber, was to forward from the main repo to the dedicated one
rather than duplicating the content
yes, and it's up to owners whether you want a dedicated repo or not
my hunch is it makes sense for async iteration or other things that are "big pieces" of design
but for polish not so much
maybe "corresponds to lang team initiative" is a rough rule of thumb for a dedicated repo?
sounds right
anyway, I think we should definitely have this done by the end of the first sprint
"wants design docs that don't have an otherwise appropriate home"? :)
as a meta point, is our goal to leave this meeting with a list of people + tasks for them?
including milestones for at least initiatives that are underway (defining this for things we :zzz: is not a bad idea but can probably be skipped)

nikomatsakis said:

as a meta point, is our goal to leave this meeting with a list of people + tasks for them?

I'd like to leave with a list of sprint goals for each area, hopefully each goal also has a person attached :)

• Discuss meeting structure

is the next agenda item
I suppose here is where we should talk about the general concept of sprints
@nikomatsakis did you want to give an intro, or should I
I'd say you do it
I'll check that it matches my expectations :)
So, I think most people have heard of sprints
Basically every 2 weeks, we talk about how the last sprint went and we set the goals for what we're going to accomplish in the next sprint
that's pretty much it :)
for us specifically
the other thing I thought we might mention is the interaction with polish
I'm thinking we should include "shared team responsibilities" in each sprint, which means what we've been referring to as "polish" issues
these are things like ICEs, bad diagnostics, etc.
I don't think these should be up to any one person to fix, or they'll just pile up
Curious to hear people's thoughts on this, though
I like the idea
more specifically, what we wanted to say was: each person in the group should aim to fix 1 polish issue per sprint
Should we use the wg-async-foundations repo as a shared backlog, and rely on labels for "things that need to be done, by anyone that has time"?
that's kind of a "minimum bar" for group membership, I think
/me notes that he hasn't really fixed 1 issue per sprint for some time :)

Esteban Küber said:

Should we use the wg-async-foundations repo as a shared backlog, and rely on labels for "things that need to be done, by anyone that has time"?

we have an existing set of issue tags for rust-lang/rust
(:point_up: with the understanding that some "polish" tickets can be larger than others :sweat_smile:)
We could use our project board to track the shared backlog. I've been thinking of reorganizing it to make it clearer what polish issues are open
my assumption is that "working on" an issue is ok too :)
presuming it is hard
yeah, I think we'll have to calibrate expectations a bit as we go.. it might be that you spend hours on an issue and it's still not fixed, but you feel like you made progress..
I'd say that it's up to @eholk to organize things in whatever way he sees fit
in terms of labels / board etc
yes
but we can all kibitz :)
please do!
yeah so I'd like to get the basic workflow for polish issues outlined by next meeting
we can iterate on it of course

As for the meeting structure itself, here's what I had in mind more specifically:

  • Check in from each area lead (preparing these ahead of time is encouraged), including:
    - Previous sprint progress
    - Next sprint goals
    - Blockers and/or ideas for making progress easier
  • Post list of items open for review
  • Other topics added to the agenda
how does this sound?
sgtm

otherwise I think we can move on

@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
The next thing I wanted to talk about was identifying initial sprint goals for each area

• Identify first (uncalibrated) sprint goals

is the agenda item
these should be as specific and actionable as possible, and also aim to be realistic
/me thinks-- 2 weeks :)
I put (uncalibrated) here because while I'd like to fit the goals to exactly what we can get done in 2 weeks, we don't actually know how much that is
I think @tmandry you and I should be able to outline the (curently understood) design space around async fn in trait in that time
yeah, that sounds right
there's also all the organizational setup we talked about
maybe we should all take 5 minutes to brainstorm these for our respective areas?
we can drop them in the agenda doc
that's a good idea

tmandry said:

there's also all the organizational setup we talked about

by this you mean, e.g., that someone could take an action item like "create the repo"
yep (and fill it out, and link to it from the wg-async-foundations)
Something I'm wondering about: I'm thinking about finishing up more work around status quo, shiny future narratives
that doesn't exactly fit any existing area
but I'm going to add it
yeah
brainstorming time is happening in case you missed it :-)
We are adding only this sprint's milestones, right?
right
correct
(brb)
ok, let's circle back in one minute
lurking. Sorry I'm late I had another meeting that ran long.
unless everyone is done already
okay, I guess now we'll do show and tell :)

General

  • Extend and land #230 -- nikomatsakis
  • Extend roadmap vision to include async fn main and to mention the "task-local auto trait" problem -- nikomatsakis
  • Apply the diffs I've been saving up in a hackmd somewhere to the roadmap -- tmandry

Async fn everywhere

  • Update the wg-async-foundations repo to link to the repository
  • Outline design space for async fn in trait + dyn async fn in trait in the initiative repo
  • Prepare a lang-team proposal for "async fn in traits"
  • Write up a charter for "async fn fundamentals"
if there are no comments
well, one question I had was whether we should make an "umbrella initiative" for "async fundamentals" which is what the repo covers
Niko thought it wasn't worth it
actually @nikomatsakis to make sure, do you see "async fn in traits" as covering both static and dyn?
I think that feels about right for a lang team initiative
back

tmandry said:

actually nikomatsakis to make sure, do you see "async fn in traits" as covering both static and dyn?

I do
ok
we may wind up with two RFCs
but I think it's one feature

next up is

Async iteration

  • T-lang proposal for async iteration item - estebank
  • Update wg-async-foundations repo to link to async-iteration repo - estebank
  • Start conversation on "async iteration expression"
    - This feature has been added to the initiative due to grouping, but no work has been done on it yet.
what is "async iteration expression" again?
oh, is that for await or whatever?
@Esteban Küber
Correct
ok
something that I haven't worked on and if we want done at some point, I need to start thinking about it
I am still fond the framing it as extending patterns, but we can discuss in said conversation :)
okay, sounds good

Hey, not to interrupt this meeting, but I was interested in getting involved in a roadmap item, but the only thing that says "help wanted" is boxable async fns, is that going to be updated, or is everything else covered?
We decided not to do boxable async fns now, actually
I think we're still figuring out places where more people can plug in
@Ibraheem Ahmed if there's something that we have in excess is work to do :)

the next section is

Polish

  • Discuss liveness-based generator captures with lang-team - eholk
  • Significant progress towards production-ready generator liveness captures - eholk
  • Reschedule weekly triage meeting to be Europe-friendly - eholk
  • Re-organize and continue to maintain project board for polish issues - eholk
  • Fix a polish bug (which one TBD) - eholk
  • Progress towards must_not_suspend lint - Gus Wynn
cc @eholk
My main focus will be on the generator capture issue, and I'm cautiously optimistic we can get most of the code for it done

One thing @Ibraheem Ahmed is that I expect us to be posting drafts and things for feedback, so there will be opportunities to help out on the design of items -- that said, I'd say that it's a good question in genearl, and that each area owner should be thinking about if/when there are places they'd like help

I have a hard stop in a few min so ill talk about mine real quick: on must_not_suspend I am planning to start looking at it this weekend, with the guidance @nikomatsakis gave on https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/83310, it looks like the other person working on it hasn't done much since mar so I think it should be fine
Otherwise, I'll be doing organization stuff and trying to help others contribute to polish issues
ok, great. I think this looks good
The other areas that have owners are "Portability across runtimes" and "Tooling", both of those owners couldn't make the meeting today, but should be able to in the future
@Gus Wynn great! let's add that to the list. We should ping the two authors but I also think they will not mind someone pitching in on the coding aspect of things!
ya and if worse case effort is duplicated and I learn how lints work in rustc, not too bad of an outcome

nikomatsakis said:

Gus Wynn great! let's add that to the list. We should ping the two authors but I also think they will not mind someone pitching in on the coding aspect of things!

the "two" authors? it looks like one person was working on that?
there were two authors of the original RFC, I think
I think the RFC + design were being worked on by both @Bhargav Voleti and @Lucio Franco

• What's still missing from our process / organization?

is the next and last agenda item

nikomatsakis said:

I think the RFC + design were being worked on by both Bhargav Voleti and Lucio Franco

and they are now pinged, nice!
basically: is there anything missing from the overall structure here that would help?
one thing I'm noticing is that we haven't thought too much about "entry vectors" for people who want to help
I feel like this process is quite new for us
I think that's ok
specifically, I think that we are kind of consciously trying to do somethign a bit different, more focused
but I thnk it's something we should keep in mind and come back to
(ah one thing we didn't talk about was the lists of stakeholders, right?)
ah you're right
shoot
Each area owner needs to identify stakeholders for their area, and list them somewhere
we're out of time now, though
but area owners, please be thinking about this :)
going to wrap up now.. :wave: thanks everyone!
https://rust-lang.github.io/wg-async-foundations/vision/how_to_vision/stakeholders.html
oh, @tmandry -- we were going to make a kind of "checklist" for area owners, right? but we never did...
d'oh
anyway, :wave:

nikomatsakis said:

oh, tmandry -- we were going to make a kind of "checklist" for area owners, right? but we never did...

you're right, let's throw that on
tmandry has marked this topic as resolved.
